channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Two new cases leaving isolation 'an unacceptable failure of the system' - Ardern
item.description: Jacinda Ardern says the incident that saw two new Covid-19 cases leaving isolation "should never have happened and cannot be repeated". Watch the PM's media conference here.

item.title: Covid-19: Number of new cases drops back to zero
item.description: There have been no new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, but the two new cases announced yesterday have had 320 close contacts, the Health Ministry has confirmed.

item.title: Four teenagers arrested, charged over school brawl
item.description: Four teenage boys between the ages of 14 and 16 have been charged with wounding with intent to injure after a brawl outside a South Auckland college.

item.title: Covid-19 isolation and quarantine facilities to be inspected
item.description: The Chief Ombudsman says new arrivals in the country were able to mingle at a hotel with other guests, including his staff.

item.title: Statues of historical and political figures more likely to be vandalised - study
item.description: Statues of royalty, politicians, military leaders and explorers have been the most regularly vandalised in recent decades, an Otago University study has found.

item.title: NZ's high number of remand prisoners 'unacceptable' - Chief Justice
item.description: The Chief Justice says work is under way to reduce delays in court cases following the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Arthur's Pass: Transport Agency at odds with communities over snow chain ban
item.description: Three mayors and thousands of road users are hoping to overturn a snow chain ban across Arthur's Pass, or come to a compromise with the Transport Agency.

item.title: National plan for training of specialists vital - Council of Medical Colleges
item.description: The wasteful duplication of expertise and training has been identified as a threat to the medical workforce in a review of the health system.

item.title: Government unveils $380m subsidy for employers training apprentices
item.description: A new government subsidy will pay employers up to $16,000 for each new apprentice they train from August.

item.title: Concerns over political influence at health boards if overhaul proceeds
item.description: A former Waikato District Health Board member, who admits he landed an earlier public health role thanks to his contacts, is worried about political patronage if a health system proposal goes ahead.

item.title: Auckland brothel murder-accused named, pleads not guilty
item.description: The man accused of murdering a 30 year old at an Epsom brothel has been named and pleaded not guilty in the High Court at Auckland.

item.title: Police halt recruitment after large increase in applications
item.description: More than 4000 people are in the recruitment process and about 600 people are applying to join each month, according to police.

item.title: Auckland family kept separated by visa denials: 'We should be allowed to be together'
item.description: An Auckland mother whose partner has been waiting nearly a year for a visa to meet their baby is appalled a nanny for an America's Cup team has been granted a visa ahead of her child's father.

item.title: Pedestrian seriously injured after being hit by train in Matamata
item.description: A person is in a critical condition after being hit by a train in Matamata.

item.title: Foreigners in New Zealand offered relief, but no cash payments
item.description: Foreigners left high and dry due to the Covid-19 crisis will now be able to apply for food, clothing, blankets and accommodation from a new assistance programme.

item.title: Sentry Taitoko inquest ends six years after death in police cell
item.description: The mother of a young man who died in an Auckland police cell six years ago says it has been a long wait for answers.

item.title: Health Minister suspends compassionate exemptions from quarantine
item.description: Clark has told RNZ's Checkpoint he has asked for all compassionate exemptions from quarantine to be temporarily suspended as a result of the two latest cases of Covid-19.

item.title: Firearms reform set to progress in Parliament
item.description: Senior Labour ministers are playing down any influence coalition partner New Zealand First had on changes to firearms law, soon to be ushered through Parliament.
